syntax.code:
# This is a comment
print("Hello!") # This is also a comment
syntax.description: Comments start with the # symbol. Python ignores everything after that on the same line. Use comments to explain your code.

content.content: A comment is a note in your code that Python does not run. It's for you or other people reading the code. It starts with a # symbol.
Comments explain what your code does. This helps others (and your future self) understand your thinking. They are useful for debugging, reminders, and documentation.
Just type # and then your note. You can put a comment on its own line, or at the end of a line of code.
No, but they’re a good habit. Clear comments make your code easier to understand and maintain.
Comments do not affect how your program runs. You can add or remove them without changing the behavior of your code.
Python doesn’t have a special symbol for multi-line comments. You can write several single-line comments in a row, or use a string (like '''text''') if you only need to block out code temporarily.
